scenario:
Consolidated Edison, NextEra Energy, and Southern Company are considered recession-resistant due to their stable earnings and consistent dividend growth. These utilities have increased their payouts for over 20 years, including during severe recessions. They are great stocks to buy if a recession is anticipated.

Consolidated Edison has a 51st consecutive year of dividend hikes, maintaining its position as a Dividend King. It has a conservative dividend payout ratio (55-65% of adjusted earnings) and a strong balance sheet, enabling it to continue investing in expanding its utility infrastructure.

NextEra Energy has increased its dividend every year for the past three decades, with a 10% annual growth rate over the past 20 years. The company targets 10% annual dividend growth and expects to grow its adjusted earnings per share by 6-8% annually through 2027.

Southern Company has paid a dividend equal to or greater than the previous year for 77 years and increased its payment for 23 years in a row. The company plans to invest $63 billion through 2029 to support growing power demand in the South, powering 5-7% annual earnings growth and continued dividend increases.

Utilities operate recession-resilient businesses due to steady demand for electricity and gas, and government-regulated rate structures. This stability makes them a great way to diversify a portfolio and mute the impact of future recessions.
